awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Identification of Effective Heat Conductivity Coefficient of Particulate Two-phase Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Savannah State University focuses on mathematical modeling for the identification of heat conductivity coefficients of two-phase materials and provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to enhance their education through research experiences in mathematical modeling. The researcher has established a strong collaboration with faculty at Purdue University. 

One of the central issues of the contemporary mechanics of continuous media is the problem of identification of the mechanical properties of particulate two-phase materials and flows based on the respective properties of the constituents. This project will investigate the problem of identifying one such mechanical property, namely, effective heat conductivity.  The particulate material (or suspension of particles in a fluid, such as a liquid-solid mixture) can be conceptualized as a particulate "phase" comprised of randomly dispersed particles throughout a continuous "phase". The presence of suspended particles strongly influences the overall mechanical properties. This phenomenon remains a major challenge in the field of fluid mechanics especially while estimating the effective transport coefficients, such as the heat conductivity coefficient or the viscosity coefficient, of suspensions. The long-term goal is the estimation of the effective heat conductivity coefficient for suspension by developing an in-depth mathematical model. This model will be based on a system of stochastic differential equations. This system will be recovered from the steady and unsteady heat diffusion equations by applying a method called random point approximations - also, expanding the temperature field by using a suitable stochastic functional series. In this process, the model will be fully capable of countering the problems associated with the randomness of sizes and positions of the suspended particles in a continuous media. Furthermore, it will also be able to tackle the significant issue of inhomogeneity interactions which is strongly validated by experimental data. Once developed, this model will lead to a mathematically rigorous formula for effective heat conductivity coefficient of suspension, improving Maxwell's formula for terms up to the square of concentration of the suspension. The expected outcomes will also improve our understanding of the mechanism and theory that underlies this phenomenon which will subsequently extend design options in manufacturing devices and developing processes applicable to these mechanisms, therefore opening the door to possibilities of novel processes and devices that use heat transfer and fluid flow.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to develop a rigorous mathematical model for quantifying the effective heat conductivity coefficient for suspension. To illustrate the case of effective heat conductivity for suspensions, one can consider the example of air bubble dispersed over the beer liquid as a heterogeneous two-phase flow or suspension. Since the liquid and air have different heat conductivity coefficients, the effective heat conductivity coefficient of the newly formed suspension cannot be obtained by merely averaging their individual heat conductivity coefficients. This is mainly due to the fact that the size and positions of the bubbles cannot be controlled. So, one must introduce a system of stochastic differential equations that will describe the flow of the bubbles in the suspension.

This whole idea is based on the seminal works John Maxwell and Albert Einstein who were the first to identify the overall electric conductivity coefficient and viscosity coefficient, respectively, by creating a suspension which includes single sphere only. In other word, coefficients are obtained as an infinite series with respect to the volume fraction of the suspension but truncated only after the first order since only one sphere is used. It automatically leads to the next problem of introducing two spheres into a homogeneous media in order to turn it into a suspension/heterogeneous media. But finding the second order in the volume fraction is a particularly challenging mathematical problem. Despite the extensive literature on the subject, a unified and rigorous mathematical approach has not yet been developed and each particular physical situation has to be treated separately. This problem is formidable mainly because it is a three-dimensional problem and more importantly, there is no strong mathematical evidence of how fiercely a sphere interacts with another sphere when they are reasonably close to each other. This is immensely significant while dealing with dense suspension. Addressing this problem became imperative towards solving the system of stochastic differential equations to find the effective transport coefficients to the second order with respect to volume fraction which had been reviewed in the current project.

The PI and his research collaborator have developed a semi-analytical mathematical model to determine the effective heat conductivity coefficient of a suspension correct up to the second order in the volume fraction. The formula is presented in closed form by using hypergeometric functions. The developed mathematical model is an improvement upon existing models because it is free from the limitations which adversely impact the effectiveness of existing models – therefore offering real world benefits while working with suspensions in diverse industries.  

This project resulted in the training of six undergraduates in the mathematics program at Savannah State University (SSU), with the majority of them from minority groups. Two of them are from the female African American group. Five of these students went on to pursue graduate programs in Mathematics either at SSU or from nationally reputed MS program at other institutions. Two of these five students have completed their MS theses under the PI’s supervision. One has joined a Software Company (SAS) and the other is working in education field. The sixth research trainee, currently a junior, is planning to pursue graduate studies in epidemiological/medical related discipline. Each student gained valuable skills in scientific computations and coding in at least one of MATLAB/Python/Mathematica which will enhance their overall employability. Each one of them was also trained in preparing professional poster and oral presentations.  

The RAs presented their research work at various meetings/conferences:

  1. 2018, 2019 - SSU Annual Research Conference, Savannah, GA
  2. 2019 - Emerging Researcher National (ERN) Conference, Washington D.C.
  3. 2019 - National Council of Undergrad Research, Kennesaw State University, Kennesaw, GA
  4. 2020 - Eagle Undergraduate Mathematics Conference, Georgia State University, Statesboro, GA
  5. MathFest'22, MathFest'23 - Troy Undergrad Research Conference, Troy University, Troy, AL.
  6. 2023 - Mathematical Association of America (MAA) Southeast Sectional meeting, Coastal Carolina University, Conway, SC.

 The PI, RAs and his collaborators wrote five manuscripts to report their results to the mathematical communities out of which, three are already published.

   The PI presented his collaborative research at conferences such as:

  1. 2018, 2020 - 71st and 73rd (virtual) APS - Division of Fluid Dynamics Meetings
  2. 2020 - HBCU-UP/CREST PI-PD Meetings
  3. 2021, 2022 - 13th and 14th Conferences of the Euro-American Consortium for Promoting the Application of Mathematics in Technical and Natural Sciences (virtual).
  4. 2022 - 12th IMACS International Conference on Nonlinear Evolution Equations and Wave Phenomena, Athens, GA.
  5. 2022 - The 6th International Virtual Workshop on Nonlinear and Modern Mathematical Physics.
  6. 2023 - American Mathematical Society Eastern Sectional Meeting (virtual).

The PI and RAs have actively participated in recruiting high school students and SSU undergraduates to become mathematics major through the dissemination of their research. Overall, their research activities and enthusiasm created a positive atmosphere for others to be interested in mathematics.

 


Last Modified: 05/14/2024
Modified by: Abhinandan Chowdhury
